author: By Eve Sampson
title: Philippines Reports First Mpox Case Since W.H.O. Declared Global Emergency
description: It was not clear if the patient had contracted the new, potentially more deadly strain of the disease, which first appeared outside of Africa in Sweden last week.
content: The Philippines reported its first case this year of mpox, previously known as monkeypox, on Monday, just days after the World Health Organization declared the disease a global health emergency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni, Maureen Dowd, Michelle Goldberg and Patrick Healy
title: Four Writers on Kamala Harris, Hillary Clinton and How to Win the White House
description: Two women seeking the White House, two historic elections: what will it take to beat Donald Trump this time?
content: Patrick Healy: The Democratic convention will be bookended by two historic figures: Hillary Clinton, the first woman nominated for president of a major party, will speak on Monday night, and Kamala Harris on Thursday night will become the second woman nominated to lead America. Maureen, Michelle, Frank: The four of us covered Clinton over the years, and now write about Harris. Clinton and Harris are approaching history pretty differently. For one thing, Clinton leaned into gender in 2016, talking about breaking the glass ceiling. And she won a big vote from women, but her percentage of the women’s vote was a little less than Barack Obama’s — and she had a slightly wider gender gap. Maureen, how do Clinton and Harris differ in how they deal with gender?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Taitz
title: How to Strengthen Your Happiness Muscle
description: Psychologists call it reward sensitivity. And simple steps can help you boost your drive to seek out positive emotions and enjoy life.
content: We’ve all experienced it: the urge to withdraw and duck experiences we know we’ll enjoy — even when a mood boost is what we need most. We skip the birthday party. We cancel lunch. They just don’t seem worth the effort. And then, more likely than not, we feel worse than we did before.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: At Least 1 Dead and 6 Missing After Yacht Sinks Off Sicily
description: Fifteen other people were rescued. Expert divers were called in to carry out search operations in the deep water. Among the missing was a British software mogul, Mike Lynch.
content: At least one person was killed and six others, including a British software mogul, were missing on Monday after a sailing yacht carrying 22 people sank during a violent storm off the coast of Sicily, Italian officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael C. Bender
title: JD Vance attacks Harris and Walz for avoiding questions and then delivers his own evasive answers.
description: At a campaign event in Philadelphia, Mr. Vance criticized his rivals for avoiding the news media and then deflected questions himself.
content: Senator JD Vance of Ohio on Monday accused Vice President Kamala Harris and Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota of misleading the public about their records and taking relatively few questions on the campaign trail.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Monday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: The presidential election is less than 80 days away. This is what we’re watching.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Harmon
title: Walz Family Fertility Journey Ran Not Through I.V.F. but Another Common Treatment
description: Unlike in vitro fertilization, the procedure used by the Walzes does not involve lab-created embryos that may be discarded, so it has not been targeted by anti-abortion leaders.
content: As Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota has introduced himself to Americans through stump speeches across the country in recent weeks, he has alluded to a journey through infertility for his family while warning that conservatives want to restrict in vitro fertilization.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: In Pennsylvania, Trump Goes After Biden and Harris
description: As Democrats gathered in Chicago, Mr. Trump kicked off a week of events in battleground states with a speech in which he took aim at his old opponent as much as his new one.
content: Hours before President Biden was expected to speak at the Democratic National Convention on Monday, former President Donald J. Trump accused Mr. Biden of being corrupt, fell back on his insistence that the court cases against him were election interference and claimed Democrats did an “overthrow or a coup” in replacing Mr. Biden atop the ticket with Vice President Kamala Harris.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Davis O'Brien and Nicholas Nehamas
title: Harris and Walz Venture Into Less-Friendly Terrain to Court Pennsylvania Voters
description: The Democratic presidential ticket went to the crucial swing state on Sunday to visit areas that are competitive and somewhat more conservative.
content: Before their convention this week that will signal the final sprint to November, Vice President Kamala Harris and her running mate, Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota, headed out on a brief bus tour on Sunday to fire up voters in perhaps the most crucial battleground state in the 2024 election.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Young Artists Rode a $712 Million Boom. Then Came the Bust.
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, August 19, 2024.
content: “You are buying a piece of my life — a little history of me and my people.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Astead W. Herndon, Stella Tan, Mooj Zadie, Diana Nguyen, Luke Vander Ploeg, Rachelle Bonja, Brendan Klinkenberg, Paige Cowett, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell, Diane Wong, Rowan Niemisto, Corey Schreppel and Chris Wood
title: The Story of Kamala Harris
description: A look back at the vice president’s career and the moments that shaped her politics.
content: Over the next few days at the Democratic National Convention, Vice President Kamala Harris will accept her party’s nomination and reintroduce herself to American voters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri
title: John Aprea, ‘Godfather Part II’ and ‘Full House’ Actor, Dies at 83
description: He played Salvatore “Sal” Tessio in “The Godfather Part II” in 1974, and the father of a popular character on “Full House,” a sitcom.
content: John Aprea, an actor who played crooks in “The Godfather Part II” and other films, and later appeared briefly as the strict but loving father of a popular character on the sitcom “Full House,” died on Aug. 5 at his home in Los Angeles. He was 83.
source.name: The New York Times

title: High Food Prices: The Causes and the Politics
description: Readers discuss how to combat high prices. Also: The decision not to pick Josh Shapiro; preparing for campus protests; crypto’s political power.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Oreskes and Rebecca Davis O'Brien
title: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. Could Be Blocked From New York’s Ballot, Again
description: Last week, he was booted for using a fake address. This week, a suit claims that people gathering signatures for the candidate deceived voters.
content: A New York judge last week barred Robert F. Kennedy Jr. from appearing on the state’s November ballot, finding that the independent presidential candidate’s assertion that he had rented a bedroom in a friend’s home did not make him a New York resident as he had claimed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Darren Incorvaia
title: This Spider Uses a Light Show to Trick Eager Male Fireflies Into Its Web
description: In China, the arachnids seem to somehow manipulate the flashing of a caught male firefly to resemble a female’s come-hither signal.
content: Imagine being a male firefly when suddenly the telltale flashing of a female catches your eye. Enthralled, you speed toward love’s embrace — only to fly headfirst into a spider’s web. That flashy female was in fact another male firefly, himself trapped in the web, and the spider may have manipulated his light beacon to lure you in.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Gabby Sobelman
title: Hamas and Islamic Jihad Claim Responsibility for Tel Aviv Bombing
description: The two groups described the attack as a suicide bombing, but an Israeli statement did not. If confirmed, it would be the first suicide bombing in Israel in roughly eight years.
content: Hamas’s military wing and Islamic Jihad took responsibility on Monday for what they said was a suicide bombing in Tel Aviv late Sunday, and threatened further attacks because of the “continued civilian displacement and killings” of Palestinians.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: A Colorful, Crowd-Pleasing Zucchini Dinner
description: “This is an out-of-this world excellent dish! I’ve served it twice for company and all agree.”
content: Hi, I’m back from vacation!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frances Robles
title: Nicaragua Shutters 1,500 Nonprofit Groups, Many of Them Churches
description: The government of President Daniel Ortega revoked the legal status of hundreds of evangelical groups as part of its crackdown on institutions that do not bow to its authority.
content: The Nicaraguan government on Monday canceled the legal status of 1,500 nonprofit organizations — many of them evangelical religious groups — in the authoritarian government’s continued effort to quash people and institutions that are not allied with the government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs, Ernesto Londoño, Mitch Smith, Robert Chiarito and Dan Simmons
title: Outraged Over Gaza, Protesters Show Left-Wing Divisions as Convention Opens
description: A protest in Chicago on Monday, which was expected to be one of the largest of the week, drew fewer demonstrators than organizers had hoped for.
content: Follow the latest news on the Democratic National Convention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Protess, Kate Christobek and Jonah E. Bromwich
title: Prosecutors Leave Decision on Delaying Trump’s Sentencing Up to Judge
description: Lawyers for Donald J. Trump had asked to move his sentencing in Manhattan on 34 felony counts to after the election. In a letter, prosecutors disputed many of their arguments.
content: Manhattan prosecutors left the politically fraught decision of when to sentence Donald J. Trump in his criminal hush-money case to a judge, declining to endorse or oppose the former president’s request to postpone until after the November election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Balk
title: Some Republicans Will Take Center Stage at the Democratic Convention
description: At least three Republicans will have prominent speaking roles this week, as the Harris campaign taps into opposition to Donald J. Trump from within his own party.
content: The Democratic National Convention is expected to feature speeches from at least three Republicans, with a Republican hosting the convention’s second night, as Vice President Kamala Harris’s campaign seeks to highlight opposition to Donald J. Trump from within his own party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tressie McMillan Cottom
title: On Cat Ladies, Mama Bears and ‘Momala’
description: “Momala” makes for a charming political biography, but it isn’t powerful enough to counter the racial fears that nonwhite motherhood stokes in the nation.
content: While Donald Trump hides out in Mar-a-Lago, JD Vance has spent the past few weeks taking point on the G.O.P.’s continued struggle to define Kamala Harris. The Republican vice-presidential nominee’s beef with women who don’t have children, as outlined in an interview in 2021, has resurfaced. At the time, Vance derided Harris as emblematic of “childless cat ladies” who don’t have a “direct stake” in America. He now claims this “childless cat lady” routine was sarcasm, stating that he meant only that making more babies is a good thing for this nation. That still implies that not having children is un-American. It also underscores how Trump and Vance have very few pro-family policy proposals for actual babies, as opposed to talking about imagined babies that women should be having. Vance’s ham-handed attempts to have it both ways reveal the wink-wink of today’s egregious right-wing identity politics and point to the ways that this election’s identity politics might play out through innuendo and metaphor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Woman Gets 11 Years in Prison for Fatally Shooting Man She Said Trafficked Her
description: The Wisconsin Supreme Court ruled in 2022 that Chrystul Kizer could argue at trial that she had been justified in fatally shooting Randall Volar, through a state law that supports trafficking victims.
content: A Wisconsin woman who was allowed to argue that she had been justified in fatally shooting a man she said had sexually trafficked her was sentenced on Monday to 11 years in prison under a deal with prosecutors in which she pleaded guilty to a reduced charge, according to court documents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hermione Hoby
title: A Modern Whodunit Set Among Social Media’s Hall of Mirrors
description: “Swallow the Ghost,” by Eugenie Montague, is an up-to-the-minute mystery that defies convention.
content: For the general public, the worst things about the website we used to call Twitter include porn, harassment and fascism. But for writers of fiction taking up the site itself as a subject, the worst might be just how tricky it is to dramatize something that is both immaterial, in the literal sense of the word, and far from immaterial, in terms of its effect on so many lives. The novelist who decides to write a novel about a fictional novelist who is writing an imaginary novel on Twitter has only compounded the problem.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jess Bidgood
title: Democrats Say Hi — and Bye — to President Biden
description: A man who spent a lifetime seeking the presidency faces his party after it forced him to step aside.
content: When he was campaigning for the presidency in 2020, President Biden said he would be a “bridge” to a new generation of leaders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron E. Carroll
title: A $6 Billion Breakthrough or a Drop in the Bucket?
description: The government is finally negotiating drug prices.
content: Last week, the White House announced a milestone in health care policy. After decades of effort, and for the first time, the government successfully negotiated drug prices directly with pharmaceutical companies. For years, the fight to control health care prices, perhaps the most significant factor in health care spending, has felt like an unwinnable battle, so it’s no small feat that Medicare is finally flexing its negotiating muscles. But it’s also a drop in the bucket.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni and Katie Glueck
title: Hillary Clinton and Kamala Harris: Inside Their Quietly Close Bond
description: Mrs. Clinton, who lost out on becoming the first female president, has been a behind-the-scenes ally for the woman now vying to do so.
content: Hillary Clinton was on Martha’s Vineyard on Sunday, July 21, the day President Biden dropped out of the presidential race, when her phone rang. Her husband, former President Bill Clinton, had already received a call from the same number, so she knew who wanted to talk to her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: What Business Wants to Learn About Harris
description: Heading into the Democratic National Convention, many of the vice president’s policies have yet to be explained. Corporate leaders hope that will change.
content: The center of the national conversation this week turns to Chicago, as the Democratic National Convention is set to kick off on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael S. Schmidt and Tariq Panja
title: Former Investigator Assails World Anti-Doping Agency
description: The agency, which has faced intense criticism for its handling of positive tests among Chinese swimmers, should be replaced by a “truly independent” organization, its former chief investigative officer said.
content: A former chief investigator for the World Anti-Doping Agency said on Monday that the organization was “broken beyond repair” and had misled the public following disclosure of its decision not to discipline 23 elite Chinese swimmers who tested positive three years ago for a banned drug.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: How a Far-Right Takeover of Georgia’s Election Board Could Swing the Election
description: The unelected body that shapes voting rules has a new conservative majority who question the state’s 2020 results. They now have new power to influence the results in 2024.
content: Josh McKoon, the chair of the Georgia Republican Party, boasted at the state convention in late May that he had “very good news.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Weed
title: Trekking 85 Miles With Grandpa, Scuba Diving With Grandma
description: With older adults staying fit longer, many are joining their grandchildren on travel adventures like wilderness hikes, bike tours and even bungee jumping.
content: Rick Rhoads, 80, was “training like crazy” last spring, walking six miles a day — “all hills” — to get ready for his summer vacation. Mr. Rhoads, of Orcas Island, Wash., and Lucy Erent, his 15-year-old granddaughter, who lives in Prague, were planning to trek 85 miles in eight days along Scotland’s West Highland Way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: The Democratic Convention Kicks Off
description: Plus, a push for a Gaza cease-fire. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.
content: The Democratic National Convention will open tonight in Chicago with a burst of energy and optimism, fueled by the replacement of President Biden at the top of the ticket with his vice president, Kamala Harris.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir
title: Survivors of Doomsday Starvation Cult Testify Against Pastor and 93 Associates
description: An evangelical pastor in Kenya ordered his flock to shun education and medicine and starve their children to death in order to meet Jesus, witnesses in a manslaughter trial said.
content: When her parents denied her food and water for eight days, the girl said that she knew she was going to die, just like her two younger siblings. For days, her parents had beaten her when they caught her sipping water or looking for food. Famished and frail, she said they dressed her in special attire worn for death.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Aug. 19, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Monday, Aug. 19, 2024.
content: An image with an article on Friday about Mar-a-Lago, the Florida home of Donald J. Trump, becoming a center for some of the most extreme elements of the party’s MAGA wing was published in error. The photo showed Bill White, the former Democratic mayor of Houston, not the man who has visited Mar-a-Lago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon, Caitlin O'Keefe and Elisa Gutierrez
title: An Insider’s Guide to the D.N.C.
description: Leah Daughtry, a veteran of Democratic politics and conventions, on how the party got here and what to expect in Chicago.
content: The Democratic National Convention kicks off in Chicago today, less than a month after Democrats changed their nominee in a remarkable political shake-up. To get set for the week, “The Run-Up” talks with Leah Daughtry, an at-large member of the Democratic National Committee, the chief executive of the 2008 and 2016 Democratic National Conventions and a co-chair of the convention rules committee, an incredibly significant role this year given the nominee switch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiba Yazbek and Abu Bakr Bashir
title: Mother and 6 Children Are Killed in Israeli Strike in Gaza, Family Says
description: A Palestinian teacher and all her children were killed in a strike in Deir al-Balah that the Israeli military said had targeted “a significant Islamic Jihad terrorist.”
content: Hala Khattab’s home in the city of Deir al-Balah in Gaza had been full of children — six of them. There was her oldest son, Hussein, 15; her 9-year-old quadruplets, Kinan, Hamman, Lujain and Sibal; and her baby girl, Wakeen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Salam
title: For Nava Mau, ‘Baby Reindeer’ Felt Private. Then It Blew Up.
description: Mau is up for an Emmy for her performance in the hit Netflix series, making her the first transgender person to be nominated for a limited series acting Emmy.
content: Voting is underway for the 76th Primetime Emmys, and this week we are talking to several first-time Emmy nominees. The awards will be presented Sept. 15 on ABC.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Penn and Tim Gruber
title: Coal Power Defined This Minnesota Town. Can Solar Win It Over?
description: One of the nation’s largest coal-fueled electric plants is being replaced with thousands of acres of solar panels and a test of long-duration batteries.
content: The past and the future of electricity in America are perhaps most visible in a Minnesota town surrounded by potato farms and cornfields.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie J. M. Baker
title: Too Young for Teeth, but Not for Steak or Corn?
description: A growing number of parents are skipping spoon-feeding their babies and trying “baby-led weaning” instead.
content: Jenny Best was determined that her firstborn son would have a positive relationship with food from his very first bite. Years earlier, as a professional ballerina, she had struggled with disordered eating, and she wanted her son to think of food as fun.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Beckley
title: The China Hangover Is Here
description: The party is over for China’s economy, and poor nations around the world are feeling the effects.
content: In the 2000s, former President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela bet his country’s economic future on a rising China, securing tens of billions of dollars in investments and loans-for-oil deals. It paid off at first. China voraciously consumed Venezuelan oil and financed infrastructure projects, such as a high-speed railway and power plants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allan Kozinn
title: Harold Meltzer, Composer of Impossible-to-Pigeonhole Works, Dies at 58
description: His music, which was performed by many prominent ensembles, mixed melodic themes and rich textures with the sharp-edged angularity of modernism.
content: Harold Meltzer, a composer who set aside a career as a lawyer to create a highly regarded body of energetic, colorful chamber, vocal and orchestral scores that mixed accessibly melodic themes and rich ensemble textures with the sharp-edged angularity of modernism, died on Aug. 12 in Manhattan. He was 58.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman and Robert Chiarito
title: When Chaos Came to Chicago: An Oral History of the 1968 Convention Riots
description: When Democrats met that year, the violence that erupted between protesters and the police shook the nation. Here are memories of some of the people who lived it.
content: Follow the latest news on the Democratic National Convention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush and Adam Goldman
title: Iran Is to Blame for Hacking Into Trump’s Campaign, Intelligence Officials Say
description: American intelligence agencies also confirmed that the effort extended to the Biden-Harris campaign, though that bid was unsuccessful.
content: American intelligence agencies said on Monday that Iran was responsible for hacking into former President Donald J. Trump’s campaign and trying to breach the Biden-Harris campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lola Fadulu, Yan Zhuang and Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: 2 Women Die as Storm Batters New York and Connecticut
description: Flooding took over parts of Long Island, the Bronx and Connecticut, where two women were swept away by floodwaters and later died, officials said.
content: Two women died after they were swept away by floodwaters as a powerful storm battered the New York City area and parts of Connecticut, where at least 100 people were evacuated, officials said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $4 Million Homes in California
description: A three-story contemporary house in Santa Monica, a four-bedroom home in Mill Valley, and a floating house on a slip in the Santa Barbara Harbor.
content: This three-bedroom house was designed by leeMundwiler, an architecture studio based in Los Angeles and Switzerland. Parts of the exterior were crafted using custom-made panels of sand, and the roof is finished with recycled glass pebbles designed to reflect light and reduce heat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin
title: ‘World News Tonight’ Producer Named President of ABC News
description: Almin Karamehmedovic, the senior executive producer of ABC’s flagship newscast with anchor David Muir, will run Disney’s news division.
content: ABC News said on Monday that Almin Karamehmedovic, the senior executive producer of “World News Tonight with David Muir,” is the network’s next president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: ‘PST Art’ Lifts Off, as NASA Scientists Team With Artists
description: Sound collages and mechanical grass are being created with the Jet Propulsion Laboratory, in a collaboration to unlock creative pathways that “are just not open.”
content: Surveying the convoluted amalgamation of equipment in his windowless lab at NASA’s Jet Propulsion Laboratory the other day, Kevin P. Hand, a planetary scientist and astrobiologist, said he sees “a massive experiment to simulate Jupiter’s moon Europa.” But visual artists looking at the same tangle, he noted, might “see this as some sort of bizarre sculpture.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Wordle Review No. 1,158
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for August 20, 2024.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Styles Desk
title: Batty Outfits, Sappy Romances: How ‘Emily in Paris’ Keeps You Coming Back for More
description: A Styles group chat on Season 4 of the Netflix series, with its Eurovision preparations, Claude Monet pond and cardigans included.
content: This article contains spoilers for “Emily in Paris” Season 4.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Porter
title: Tuesday Briefing: U.S. Said Israel Agreed to Cease-Fire Proposal
description: Plus, opening night at the Democratic convention.
content: Secretary of State Antony Blinken said yesterday that Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu had accepted a “bridging proposal” aimed at closing the gap between Israel and Hamas on a cease-fire deal for Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pam Belluck and Jason Henry
title: A Personalized Brain Pacemaker for Parkinson’s
description: In a new frontier for deep brain stimulation, researchers used A.I. to develop individualized algorithms, which helped a skateboarder and other patients with Parkinson’s disease.
content: When Shawn Connolly was diagnosed with Parkinson’s disease nine years ago, he was a 39-year-old daredevil on a skateboard, flipping and leaping from walls, benches and dumpsters through the streets of San Francisco. He appeared in videos and magazines, and had sponsorships from skateboard makers and shops.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: The Dark Side of Shen Yun
description: The popular Chinese dance troupe has toured all over the world. But young performers described a culture of untreated injuries and emotional manipulation.
content: Good morning. It’s Monday. We’ll look at findings from The Times’s investigation of the Shen Yun dance troupe. We’ll also see what’s in the waters off New York through the eyes of divers who look for shipwrecks and treasure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: Woman Accusing Eric Adams of Assault Wrote About It Years Ago, Filing Says
description: A former Transit Police Department colleague of the mayor said she told seven people years ago that he had sexually assaulted her in 1993, according to new court filings.
content: A woman who accused Mayor Eric Adams of sexually assaulting her in 1993 told nine people about the encounter and documented her account in emails years ago, her lawyer said in a legal filing on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Farrell and Matthew Goldstein
title: Carl Icahn to Pay $2 Million to Settle S.E.C. Charges
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission had accused the billionaire investor of not disclosing that he had pledged personal stock holdings as collateral for billions of dollars in loans.
content: The activist investor Carl C. Icahn was charged by the Securities and Exchange Commission with failing to disclose that he had personally pledged his own stock as collateral for margin loans worth billions of dollars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracy Mumford, Jonathan Weisman, Luke Broadwater, Ian Stewart and Jessica Metzger
title: Division at the Democratic Convention, and G.O.P. Efforts to Impeach Joe Biden
description: Plus, a hospital system gets into show business.
content: On Today’s Episode:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Sims
title: 7 Last-Minute Escapes for Labor Day Weekend
description: If you’re still hoping to stretch out the last days of summer, there are places in North America that are not too hot, not too crowded and not necessarily that far away.
content: It might sound like an impossible request: a last-minute Labor Day getaway with gorgeous weather and minimal crowds that you can squeeze into a long weekend. There are good reasons many destinations across North America won’t fit the bill. Wildfires are burning in some parts of the West, tropical disturbances are brewing in the Caribbean, the East Coast’s coastal retreats are packed, and much of the South is sweaty and oh so steamy. But if you’re still hoping to stretch out the last days of summer, there are places that are not too hot, not too crowded and not necessarily that far away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: Jason Isbell Offers Democrats a Way to Connect With a New Audience
description: The Southern white, working man’s musician performs at the Democratic convention and lets loose on the state of politics in an interview.
content: As both a musician who channels the voices of forgotten Americans, and a white man from the South with a working-class upbringing, Jason Isbell provides hope for Democrats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: Kamala Harris Takes Her First Big Risk
description: A proposal on “price gouging” is stirring up quite a debate.
content: Bret Stephens: Hi, Gail. How do you feel about price controls?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: What’s the Next ‘Baby Reindeer’? This Producer Might Have the Script.
description: Francesca Moody has put on some of the Edinburgh Fringe’s biggest breakout hits. This year, she has three shows that she’s hoping will go global.
content: One day in fall 2018, the British theater producer Francesca Moody was rummaging around in her bag for something to read during a train ride when she found a script she’d been meaning to look at for weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski, Andrew E. Kramer, Kim Barker and Adam Rasgon
title: Ukraine Says Its Incursion Will Bring Peace. Putin’s Plans May Differ.
description: President Volodymyr Zelensky wants to hold Russian territory as leverage in future talks. In Moscow, many doubt the strategy.
content: In July, as he secretly readied an invasion of Russia, President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine sent a very different signal in public: He wanted talks to end the war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yasmena Almulla and Vivian Nereim
title: A Deadly Fire Exposes the Plight of Low-Paid Migrants in Wealthy Kuwait
description: After the blaze killed 49 migrant workers, a government crackdown focused on building violations — bypassing deeper problems that leave migrants with low wages and unsafe housing across the oil-rich Gulf.
content: On a recent summer day in Kuwait, as the temperature soared above 110 degrees, four Indian migrant workers stood by the side of a road with their belongings stuffed into bags.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alissa Wilkinson
title: I ❤️ a Hate-Watch. Don’t You?
description: TV shows that are expensively made yet irritating to sit through — for some reason, I can’t get enough of them. Why do so many of us watch things we think are bad?
content: When it premiered in 2017, I quite liked “The Bold Type,” a television series about three 20-something women working at a fictional magazine called Scarlet. Although the show could tend toward after-school special, with the characters learning important lessons about speaking your truth, facing your sexuality or getting regular gynecological examinations, its heartwarming conventions — young women living their editorial dreams in the big city — worked their magic on me.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas
title: Democrats Unveil Convention Platform With Familiar Themes
description: The party is calling for tax increases on corporations and the rich while also focusing on working families, infrastructure, climate change and abortion rights.
content: Follow the latest news on the Democratic National Convention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nagourney
title: 6 Things to Watch For at the Democratic Convention
description: Vice President Kamala Harris has never commanded a spotlight this big. The party faces potential fractures over the war in Gaza. And Hillary Clinton’s speech will be a reminder of what might have been.
content: The Democratic National Convention, which opens Monday in Chicago, will be a test for the party and its new standard-bearer, Vice President Kamala Harris, who has never been so center stage. The next few days should signal how Ms. Harris intends to define her candidacy, and will help determine whether the party can remain unified despite deep divisions over issues including the war in Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: Delaware Democrats to Their Joyous Party: ‘Et tu, Brute?’
description: Convention attendees from President Biden’s home state were careful to emphasize their support for Kamala Harris. But some still expressed a sense of loss.
content: Joyous Democrats have descended on Chicago, a city awash in Kamala Harris merchandise, memes and crowds of people eager to celebrate her White House candidacy, having long moved on from President Biden’s ill-fated run.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Lyons
title: ‘Homicide’ Is One of the Best TV Shows Ever. And It Is Finally Streaming
description: For years, the foundational cop drama, based on the book by David Simon (“The Wire”), languished in DVD-only purgatory. No longer.
content: Pop the champagne, ring the bells, dance the jigs, cancel all other plans: A time of great rejoicing is here. “Homicide: Life on the Street,” one of the greatest shows in TV history, is finally streaming (on Peacock). So long we wandered in darkness, begging for its return. How we lamented its absence while the years rolled by, our cries growing louder and more sorrowful. But now at last we feast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ann Neumann
title: Her Husband Died, Then Her Mother. Northern Ireland Offered Solace.
description: Rosie Schaap’s new memoir, “The Slow Road North,” recalls her grief and her subsequent move out of Brooklyn.
content: It is a phenomenon known to hospice workers, nurses and priests that the dying often take their last breath once their loved ones have stepped away — say, to get a cup of coffee, take a shower, catch a few minutes of precious sleep. (My own father died while I was out picking up a sandwich.) Some say it is because they are held fast in this world by our voices, hearing being the last lingering sense. When we leave the room, they drift away. But the effects of not being present for a loved one’s death can be devastating.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Jimison, Isabel Kershner, Aaron Boxerman and Michael Levenson
title: Israel Accepts Proposal to Bridge Differences on Cease-Fire, Blinken Says
description: The statement by the secretary of state put new pressure on Hamas, whose officials have called the proposal fundamentally slanted toward Israel.
content: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said on Monday that Israel had accepted a Biden administration proposal to bridge some remaining differences with Hamas on a cease-fire deal, as he pushed what he called “probably the best, maybe the last, opportunity” to secure a truce and free the remaining hostages in Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitra Taj and Marco Garro
title: The Mennonites Making the Amazon Their Home
description: Groups of Mennonites, seeking inexpensive land far from modern life, are carving out new colonies in the Amazon. They are also raising fears that they are adding to the deforestation of the vital jungle.
content: After weeks of living in jungle tents, the handful of Mennonite families trying to make a new home deep in the Peruvian Amazon began to despair. Wasps attacked as they tried to clear forest. Heavy rains turned the road to their camp to mud.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Kamala Harris’s Muscular Patriotism
description: In recent weeks, the vice president’s message has revolved around progressive patriotism.
content: At her first rally with Tim Walz, Kamala Harris delivered a riff about their quintessentially American backgrounds. She grew up in Oakland, Calif., raised by a working mother, while he grew up on the Nebraska plains, she explained. They were “two middle-class kids,” she said, now trying to make it to the White House together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein
title: What Happened to the Bus Lanes New Yorkers Were Promised?
description: Buses are often unreliable and slow (thanks to clogged streets), but even projects to ease these problems are getting delayed. Is Mayor Eric Adams to blame?
content: This is Street Wars, a weekly series on the battle for space on New York’s streets and sidewalks.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Letters! Actual Letters!
description: When the best — and perhaps only — way to say something is to write it down.
content: On This Week’s Episode:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Biden Defends His Record and Endorses Harris: ‘America, I Gave My Best to You’
description: In a 52-minute speech, President Biden made the case that Vice President Kamala Harris is the best person to carry on his legacy.
content: Follow the latest news on the Democratic National Convention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya C. Miller
title: In Nevada, Rosen Skips Convention but Hopes to Benefit From Harris’s Rise
description: Senator Jacky Rosen led her Republican opponent by double digits in two recent polls, but she is taking nothing for granted in her competitive and costly re-election race.
content: In sprawling Washoe County, the area stretching from Lake Tahoe to the Oregon border that is widely considered the most politically competitive in Nevada, a surge of enthusiasm in recent weeks has given Democrats hope that Senator Jacky Rosen, one of the party’s most vulnerable incumbents, can pull off a re-election victory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Trump Promotes A.I. Images to Falsely Suggest Taylor Swift Endorsed Him
description: The former president has been preoccupied with the popularity of the pop music megastar, who endorsed Joseph R. Biden Jr. over him during the 2020 election.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump, who has notably harbored a grudge against the pop music megastar Taylor Swift, set the internet ablaze on Sunday when he shared social media posts suggesting that she had endorsed him and that her fans could help him win the November election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas
title: Highlights From Night 1 of the Democratic Convention
description: Speeches by President Biden and Hillary Clinton symbolized how Democrats are moving on from the old guard that has led their party for decades.
content: In a city where he was supposed to claim the mantle of the Democratic Party for the final time, at a convention where he was supposed to cement his political legacy, President Biden instead passed the torch of leadership, wiping away tears as the crowd rose to its feet in a sustained ovation and chanted, “Thank you, Joe.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Oreskes
title: Harris’s Candidacy Boosts a Democrat’s Slim Chances on Long Island
description: Representative Nick LaLota is questioning John Avlon’s local bona fides as they battle over who is more authentically of Long Island.
content: Out at the exclusive East End of Long Island, John Avlon, the former CNN commentator now running for Congress, seemed quite at home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: Harris’s Economic Plan Isn’t Perfect, but It’s Better Than Trump’s
description: She’s right to focus on the high cost of living, even if the details could use some tweaks.
content: Old joke: If you teach a parrot to say “supply” and “demand,” you’ve got yourself a fine economist. I imagined I had a parrot economist on my shoulder when I listened to Vice President Kamala Harris’s economic speech on Friday in Raleigh, N.C.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roslyn Sulcas
title: The Godfather of French Contemporary Dance Passes the Torch
description: Jean-Paul Montanari’s career as the head of Montpellier Danse has been entwined with the rise of contemporary dance as a force in France.
content: “But is he really leaving?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith
title: Convention Gives Chicago’s Mayor His Biggest Platform and His Biggest Test
description: As his city hosts the Democrats, Mayor Brandon Johnson wants to change how the world sees Chicago. But protests bring uncertainty, and the convention carries risks.
content: Follow the latest news on the Democratic National Convention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Grace Ashford, Michael Gold, Nicholas Fandos and Nate Schweber
title: George Santos Pleads Guilty to Wire Fraud and Identity Theft
description: Mr. Santos, a former Republican congressman from New York, agreed to pay nearly $375,000 in restitution and faces a minimum of two years in prison.
content: George Santos, the disgraced former Republican congressman from New York whose penchant for lying led to one of the oddest sideshows in modern U.S. politics, pleaded guilty on Monday to wire fraud and aggravated identity theft and admitted to an array of other frauds and deceits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: Ukraine Strikes Bridges in Russia, Aiming to Entrap Troops
description: The attacks aim to destroy or damage crossings over a river in the Kursk region that are Russian forces’ only routes for resupply or retreat, military analysts say.
content: Russian troops defending a pocket of territory wedged between a river and the border with Ukraine were at risk of becoming encircled, military analysts said Monday, after Ukraine bombed bridges that are the only routes for resupply or retreat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert D. McFadden
title: Ruth Johnson Colvin, Champion of Literacy, Is Dead at 107
description: Working out of her basement, and with no teaching experience, she created a nonprofit that helped people around the world learn to read.
content: Ruth Johnson Colvin, who founded what became one of the world’s largest organizations of volunteers tutoring basic language skills to functionally illiterate peoples in America and other lands, opening doors to citizenship and better lives, died on Sunday at her home in Syracuse, N.Y. She was 107.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Pogue
title: The Senator Warning Democrats of a Crisis Unfolding Beneath Their Noses
description: Chris Murphy has been trying to understand why our version of liberalism — emphasizing free markets and consumer choice — feels to many like a dead end.
content: In December 2022, early into what he now describes as his political journey, Senator Chris Murphy of Connecticut gave a speech warning his fellow Democrats that they were ignoring a crisis staring them in the face.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Maddow
title: Rachel Maddow: What Worries Me Most About Election Night
description: Georgia Republicans have empowered local election officials to delay certifying the vote.
content: On Dec. 1, 1960, the far-right preacher and racist demagogue Gerald L.K. Smith sent out a fund-raising appeal, headlined with a shocking claim in red type across the top: “HOLD YOUR BREATH: KENNEDY MAY HAVE LOST.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman
title: Jury Finds Parents of Gunman Not Liable in 2018 Texas School Shooting
description: Jurors decided instead that blame rested with the gunman, who was 17 at the time, and the company that sold him ammunition used in the shooting.
content: The parents of a gunman who was 17 when he killed eight students and two teachers at his high school in Santa Fe, Texas, in 2018 are not financially liable for his heinous actions, a jury found on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: Trying to Recover the British Museum’s Gems, and Its Reputation
description: The police haven’t charged anybody over the missing artifacts, but the museum is running its own investigations to get the items back.
content: A year has passed since the British Museum said it had fired a curator for stealing from its supposedly lock-tight storerooms and selling the artifacts online. Ever since, the museum has struggled to deal with the fallout from the scandal, which has battered its reputation as a protector of world treasures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer
title: 3 Women With Harrowing Pregnancy Stories Will Speak at Convention
description: The three women, who have been supporting the Democrats’ presidential campaign, will on Monday focus on abortion rights, a key pillar of the party’s policy goals.
content: Democrats on Monday evening will spotlight the stories of women placed in medical peril because of state abortion bans, part of an effort by the party to capitalize on the lasting anger over the Supreme Court’s decision in 2022 to overturn Roe v. Wade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: House G.O.P. Makes Impeachment Case Against Biden Without Proof of Crime
description: In a lengthy report released on the first day of the Democratic National Convention, Republicans used circumstantial evidence to accuse the president of corruption tied to his son’s foreign business dealings.
content: House Republicans on Monday formally made the case for impeaching President Biden, releasing a lengthy report accusing him of corruption and seeking to allow his family to profit off his office in connection with foreign business deals made by his son Hunter, who has been charged with felony tax crimes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacob Bernstein
title: Alain Delon, Godfather of the Belted Trench
description: As a titan of French cinema, he dressed the part, even when playing a killer.
content: Alain Delon, the French film star who died on Sunday at 88, was not big on smiling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabelle Taft
title: What Are Protesters’ Rights During the D.N.C.?
description: The boundaries of First Amendment rights and the government’s duty to maintain public order threaten to collide this week.
content: The First Amendment protects the right to assemble peaceably and protest, but courts have also recognized the right of the government to impose some restrictions on protests in the interest of safety and public order. Where are the boundary lines when those rights threaten to collide?
source.name: The New York Times

title: Jennifer Egan Looks Back at ‘A Visit From the Goon Squad’
description: The fourth in a series of conversations with authors appearing on our “Best Books of the 21st Century” list.
content: As part of its recent “100 Best Books of the 21st Century” project, The New York Times Book Review is interviewing some of the authors whose books appeared on the list. This week, Jennifer Egan joins host Gilbert Cruz to discuss her Pulitzer-winning novel about the music industry, “A Visit From the Goon Squad” (2010), and talks, among other things, about the early challenges it faced in finding an audience, the meaning of its title and her initial reluctance to decide whether the book was a novel or a story collection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Alan Cumming on ‘Chimp Crazy’: ‘I Really Do Understand the Deep Love’
description: A documentary series by a director of “Tiger King” tells a wild tale about human-chimp relationships. The actor and activist landed right in the middle.
content: In 1997, Alan Cumming appeared in the film “Buddy,” playing an animal handler hired by an eccentric socialite (Rene Russo) who maintained a menagerie in her Long Island home. One of his co-stars was Tonka, a male chimpanzee on the cusp of adolescence. Cumming felt a special bond with Tonka.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By River Akira Davis
title: 7-Eleven Gets Buyout Offer From Canadian Owner of Circle K
description: Japan’s Seven & i Holdings, which operates 85,000 stores, said it had received a bid from the Canadian convenience store chain Alimentation Couche-Tard.
content: A Canadian convenience store giant wants to buy the Japanese company that operates 7-Eleven in a deal that would create one of the world’s largest retail groups.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Teddy Rosenbluth
title: A New Treatment for Severe Allergic Reactions — Without the Needle
description: A nasal spray can tamp down potentially fatal reactions, a boon to the many patients in crisis who fear using EpiPens.
content: Dr. Michael Blaiss, an allergist at the Medical College of Georgia, was often surprised by how hesitant his patients were to use their auto-injectors, syringe-like devices like the EpiPen that deliver a drug needed to head off potentially fatal allergic reactions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: Democrats’ Unity Convention Has One Giant Exception: The Gaza War
description: Harris campaign officials and Democratic leaders have stepped up outreach to Arab and Jewish voters before the event, but large protests are still expected.
content: Follow the latest news on the Democratic National Convention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Kamalanomics, Revealed: A Solid Center-Left Agenda
description: And no, she hasn’t called for price controls.
content: On Friday, Vice President Kamala Harris gave her first big economic policy speech as the Democratic presidential nominee. It was, of course, very different from the “economic” speech and news conferences Donald Trump has held in the past couple of weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Salam
title: 3 Episodes That Explain Phil Donahue’s Daytime Dominance
description: In his very first episode, which aired locally in Dayton, Ohio, the host, who would go on to redefine such talk shows, interviewed one of the most notorious figures in America.
content: Phil Donahue, who died on Sunday at age 88, will long be remembered as the king of daytime television.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Here’s the Speaker Lineup for the Opening Night of the Democratic Convention
description: Monday’s headliners include President Biden and the first lady, Jill Biden, along with Hillary Clinton, who was defeated by Donald J. Trump in the 2016 election.
content: Democrats have cemented the lineup of speakers for the first night of their convention in Chicago, one that blends nostalgic tributes to President Biden with blunt messaging about the threat of a second Donald J. Trump presidency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William Grimes
title: Michel Guérard, Who Lowered the Calories in Haute Cuisine, Dies at 91
description: Appalled by the food options available to those seeking to lose weight, he developed a form of nouvelle cuisine for dieters at a spa in southwestern France.
content: Michel Guérard, a driving force behind the 1960s culinary movement known as nouvelle cuisine and the creator of the enormously influential “slimming cuisine” at his 19th-century spa in Eugénie-les-Bains, France, died at his home there. He was 91.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Warning Signs Flash in a Labor Survey as Fed Officials Watch for Weakness
description: The New York Fed’s labor market survey showed cracks just as Jerome H. Powell, the Fed chair, prepares for a closely watched Friday speech.
content: Americans are increasingly worried about losing their jobs, a new survey from the Federal Reserve Bank of New York released on Monday showed, a worrying sign at a moment when economists and central bankers are warily monitoring for cracks in the job market.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Climate Groups Begin $55 Million Ad Campaign for Kamala Harris
description: Three of the ads frame Biden-Harris policies in terms of their economic, rather than environmental, benefits.
content: Several organizations focused on combating climate change joined forces on Monday for a $55 million advertising campaign in support of Vice President Kamala Harris, embracing what they describe as the economic upside of the Democratic Party’s environmental efforts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jazmine Ulloa
title: Harris Campaign Starts a WhatsApp Channel to Target Latino Voters
description: More than half of U.S. Latinos are estimated to regularly use the app to send texts and make calls, but it has also been a major source of misinformation.
content: For the past few election cycles, the messaging app WhatsApp has been a major source of news and connection — and misinformation — for Latinos in the United States, a forum to swap memes, jokes and emojis with one another across the nation and Latin America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: honorarium
description: This word has appeared in two articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word honorarium has appeared two times on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Sept. 26 in The New York Times Style Magazine article “Where the Artists Are Present — and in Charge” by Jennifer Wilson:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Noble Maillard
title: 5 Tips for Making a School Lunch Your Kid Will Actually Eat
description: With just a few tweaks and a smidgen of planning, you can pack lunches that come home eaten.
content: When it comes to making lunch for her five boys, reality and aspiration diverge for Lisa Pilcher, a finance director in Chicago. “In my head, I’m the mom who creates beautiful bento boxes with love notes to my kids,” she says. “In reality, it is an Uncrustables sandwich and a semi-moldy piece of fruit.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Harris’s Early Campaign: Heavy on Buzz, Light on Policy
description: On policy, the vice president is drafting off President Biden, essentially cherry-picking the most popular parts of his agenda and betting that a younger messenger can sell them to Americans.
content: Follow the latest news on Kamala Harris and the Democratic National Convention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shivani Gonzalez
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘The Anonymous’ and the Democratic National Convention
description: A new competition show airs on USA and Bravo. And Kamala Harris will be officially nominated as the party’s candidate across networks.
content: For those who still enjoy a cable subscription, here is a selection of cable and network TV shows, movies and specials that broadcast this week, Aug. 19-25. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon Otterman
title: Most Columbia Students Arrested During Protests Will Return to Campus
description: Some students who were arrested after setting up tents on campus or occupying a university building last spring are still on probation. Others could face consequences later this year.
content: Most Columbia University students who were arrested or faced discipline for participating in pro-Palestinian demonstrations will be able to return to campus this fall, according to information released Monday by a Congressional committee investigating the school’s response to antisemitism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 436
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Tuesday, Aug. 20, 2024.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens and Chris Hamby
title: Matthew Perry’s Death Shines a Harsh Light on Ketamine Treatment
description: Was Mr. Perry, whose struggles with substance abuse were widely known, a good candidate for a drug used to relieve depression? Doctors say his case raises thorny questions.
content: The actor Matthew Perry, who had long struggled with addiction, grew intrigued by ketamine a few years ago during a stay at a rehab facility in Switzerland where he received daily infusions of the powerful anesthetic “to ease pain and help with depression.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hope Reese
title: 5 Books to Make Caregiving a Little More Manageable
description: Health care professionals and other experts shared recommendations for anyone providing and receiving care.
content: Tina Sadarangani, a geriatric nurse practitioner in New York City, has spent years working with older adults and their families. She counsels patients on the medications they should take, the eating habits they should change and the specialists they should see.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffery C. Mays
title: Yusef Salaam, of ‘Central Park 5,’ to Speak at Democratic Convention
description: Mr. Salaam will be joined onstage in Chicago by three other men he was wrongly convicted with and will speak about the dangers of re-electing Donald Trump.
content: Yusef Salaam, a city councilman from Harlem, was one of five Black and Latino men exonerated in the rape and assault of a white female jogger in Central Park in 1989. Former President Donald J. Trump, who is white, took out full-page advertisements in four newspapers, including The New York Times, calling for the death penalty to be reinstated because of the case.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter S. Goodman
title: Businesses Are Already Girding for Next Phase of the U.S.-China Trade War
description: Alarmed by the prospect of increased tariffs on Chinese goods if Donald Trump is elected, some American companies are stockpiling parts and delaying expansions.
content: If not for the trade war between the world’s two largest economies, Easy Signs would now be hiring dozens of workers at its factory in Allentown, Pa. It would be readying plans to build a second plant somewhere out West — Salt Lake City was a contender — generating another 100 jobs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní
title: New York City Moves to Shut Down a Growing Migrant Encampment
description: Dozens of migrants have been sleeping outdoors near a large shelter complex on Randall’s Island. On Monday, the city forced them to pack up their tents and move.
content: New York City officials began clearing out an encampment of homeless migrants on Randall’s Island on Monday as the city contends with a growing number of migrants sleeping outside.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Watkins
title: What to Know About the Blue Supermoon
description: The celestial event, which is visible from Sunday to Wednesday morning, probably won’t happen again until 2037.
content: Stargazers are being treated to an astronomical show this week as an infrequent blue supermoon lights up the night sky, one of the largest and brightest full moons of the year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clyde Haberman
title: Phil Donahue, Talk Host Who Made Audiences Part of the Show, Dies at 88
description: Stalking the aisles, microphone in hand, he turned “The Phil Donahue Show” into a participation event, soliciting questions and comments on topics from human rights to orgies.
content: Phil Donahue, who in the 1960s reinvented the television talk show with a democratic flourish, inviting audiences to question his guests on topics as resolutely high-minded as human rights and international relations, and as unblushingly lowbrow as male strippers and safe-sex orgies, died on Sunday at his home on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. He was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hank Sanders
title: U.S. Soldier’s Remains Identified More Than 80 Years After Bataan Death March
description: Pvt. William E. Calkins of Oregon survived the march but died in a prison camp during World War II. His remains are set to be buried next month.
content: The remains of a U.S. soldier who survived the Bataan Death March during World War II but died in a prison camp have been identified and will be buried in Oregon, a Defense Department agency said last week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: Sparing the Horse, Brussels Warms Up to the Electric Carriage
description: The city’s last horse-drawn carriage operator says business is good since making the switch, placing the Belgian capital in the vanguard of a global change.
content: It started a number of years ago with angry remarks from tourists every now and again. But in recent years, the comments flew all of the time, with people shouting, “Shame!” at Thibault Danthine, a horse-drawn carriage operator in Brussels, as they walked by.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David French and Kristina Samulewski
title: David French on the Pro-Life Case for Kamala Harris
description: “I’m voting against Trump precisely because I’m conservative,” the columnist says.
content: David French, an Opinion columnist, is an evangelical, pro-life conservative. For the first time in his life, he plans to vote for a Democratic presidential candidate: Kamala Harris.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. D. Biersdorfer
title: How Well Do You Know Rome, and These Books Set in the City?
description: Try this short literary geography quiz focused on Italy’s ancient capital.
content: Try this short literary geography quiz focused on Italy’s ancient capital.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Bloch, William B. Davis, Madison Dong, Judson Jones, John Keefe and Bea Malsky
title: Tracking Tropical Storm Gilma
description: See the likely path and wind arrival times for Gilma.
content: See the likely path and wind arrival times for Gilma.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein, Gabriel Blanco, Alexandra Ostasiewicz, Farah Otero-Amad and Laura Salaberry
title: The Midwest Takes Center Stage at the Democratic Convention
description: The Midwest is having a moment in American politics. Reid J. Epstein, a New York Times reporter covering politics who grew up in Illinois, discusses what that means as the Democrats begin their convention in Chicago.
content: The Midwest is having a moment in American politics. Reid J. Epstein, a New York Times reporter covering politics who grew up in Illinois, discusses what that means as the Democrats begin their convention in Chicago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Flash Flooding Strands People in Connecticut
description: In Oxford, Conn., a restaurant and its parking lot flooded, trapping more than a dozen people inside until a volunteer fire department came to help.
content: In Oxford, Conn., a restaurant and its parking lot flooded, trapping more than a dozen people inside until a volunteer fire department came to help.
source.name: The New York Times
